text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
calm with colcannon hash that's right I
realize the st. Patrick's Day brunch is
not really a thing but if it were this
would be perfect and yes as the name
would indicate it is inspired by the
famous Irish potato side dish which I
could describe right now for those of
you that don't know what that is but I'm
not going to since we did a video for
that a couple years ago so we will
provide a link so you can check that out
it's basically mashed potatoes with
benefits but anyway let's go ahead get
started with the only ingredient that
prevents this dish from being vegetarian
a couple ounces of diced up pancetta
which we are going to crisp up in a
little bit of vegetable oil over medium
heat and yes you can definitely use
bacon here as many of you already know
the only difference between pancetta and
bacon is the bacon is smoked and
pancetta is not so it really just
depends if you're going for that smoky
bacon flavor or more of a pure unsmoked
porkiness so up to you you are the
Johnny Cash of what meat to put in your
hash but regardless no matter what you
use we're going to cook that over medium
heat until it's pretty much crisp and
most of that fat is rendered out and
it's that reserve fat in which we're
going to cook our potatoes so what we
want to do when our bacon or pancetta is
done is remove that with a slotted spoon
and of course we're going to reserve
that we'll add that back in later and
then like I said in that reserved fat we
will cook our diced potatoes which I'm
going to show you how to prep right now
so I have two large peeled russet
potatoes and what we'll do is we'll cut
one slice off so our potato lays flat
but not some random sized slice we'll
make that slice about 3/8 of an inch
since that's the size we want these
potato cubes to be and once that's done
and we know our potatoes not going to
move
we'll continue by slicing the potato
across like this in two yes three
eighths inch thick slices and then doing
half a potato at a time we will flip
that over on its side and cut this into
3/8 inch thick strips man that's hard to
say and then of course once we've cut
slices and then strips we can turn it
this way and cut across approximately
every 3/8 of an inch
we should get a beautifully consistent
dice where virtually all those cubes are
about the same size but what about the
ones that aren't nevermind about those
we got to move to the next step which is
to transfer into a nice bowl of fresh
cold water so I diced up two potatoes
and
furtive into some water and the reason
we're doing this is because these are
going to cook up better if we wash off
some of the starch so what we'll do is
we'll get that a little rinse and then
change the water and do that a couple
times until the water is clear and then
once that's been accomplished we'll
transfer that into a colander spin it
exactly once for no apparent reason and
let it sit there to drain very
thoroughly and then once we think our
diced buds are dry enough we will go
back over to the stove where we will
heat our reserved fat on medium-high
heat and we will go ahead and add our
diced potatoes and by the way I should
mention I tried to use the manual light
exposure on the camera which did not
work at all I really should read the
manual in these days but anyway we will
add our potatoes and try to distribute
them and do a single layer and of course
we're going to want to season these up
so I'm gonna go ahead and add some
kosher salt as well as some freshly
ground black pepper and we'll go ahead
and we'll stir all that together and
then all we're going to do is continue
cooking on medium to medium-high heat
until our potatoes are a nice golden
brown and I said cook stirring but don't
stir too much okay we're going to want
those to sit for like three or four
minute stretches where they're just
crusting onto the bottom so leave them
alone for a few minutes and then give
them a stir and then kind of move stuff
around Pat it down into a single layer
again and we'll simply repeat that
process until they're a beautiful golden
brown and don't let the editing fool you
which makes it look like I'm just during
these continually I'm not after I stir
am I even I'm back out
I let them crust up for a few minutes
and then I give another stir so I kept
doing that until basically mine look
like this which by the way if I was just
making a plain potato hash I would go a
little further but these are going to
cook even further when we add the green
onions which is the next step so at this
point we're going to stop and toss in
just a little touch of butter along with
a whole bunch of sliced spring onions
also known as green onions also known as
scallions and a few other names but
three names is enough so we'll stir that
in and continue cooking on about
medium-high heat maybe a little bit
below you have to adjust the heat based
on what you're seeing in the pan of
course we're going to continue cooking
that until our onions soften up a little
bit and our potatoes continue to get
even more beautiful and I should mention
at this point if you want you can take a
leak and do the exact same thing we did
here with the green onion it pretty much
works just this
and one could argue with the leak you
might even get a little better flavor
but anyway like I said we're going to
continue cooking until we've determined
our potato cubes are gorgeous and our
green onions have sweetened and softened
up a little bit and then what we'll do
at this point is add back in our cooked
pancetta or bacon and we'll stir that in
and then the only other thing we're
going to need to add to this is our
chopped Cal which by the way we will do
at some point while our potato and onion
mixture are cooking and to make life
easy for myself what I have here is a
couple big handfuls of baby kale which
not only came triple washed for my
convenience but because we're using the
nice tender baby kale we don't have to
pull off or trim off any of those tough
stems so we'll go ahead and we'll give
our Cal the old choppa choppa at which
point we can stir that into our potato
hash mixture and believe it or not as
soon as that wilt in which is only going
to take you a minute or two we are ready
to serve except for one very secret very
important ingredient as soon as that
kale wilts I'm going to quickly stir in
a little bit of sharp cheddar cheese
preferably Irish and that's going to add
just a little bit of sharpness a little
bit of richness and of course a very
subtle cheesiness so we will stir that
in and believe it or not that's it and I
know you were going to do it anyway but
just a little friendly reminder make
sure you taste this for salt and other
seasonings before you serve it but
anyway we're going to spoon that up and
then top it with one and/or two
perfectly poached eggs and then we'll
finish with a little kiss of cayenne as
well as a nice big sprinkling a freshly
chopped Italian parsley and I
specifically picked a nice light lime
green placemat to really bring out those
colors in the hash and it worked
perfectly for having the opposite effect
so as you'll see I lost the placement
which helped a little very little and
then I was going to mention some notes
but I forgot it was because all I could
think about was grabbing a fork and
busting that egg right in the yolk so
that's what I did and look at that that
egg is so perfect I don't even need slow
motion here but forget the physical
beauty it really is the tastes and
textures here that I enjoy so much okay
we have that amazing buttery green onion
crusty potato mixture plus that savory
hit from the pancetta
and a little bit of richness from the
cheese and then all that's balanced by
our delicious and nutritious bitter
greens in the form of our kale so just a
great example were some very basic
simple ingredients come together to make
something quite special so anyway that's
it
whether you're playing to make the
seasonal treat for Easter or Mother's
Day or you actually do use it for st.
Patrick's Day brunch and turn Erin go
bra into Erin go breakfast no matter
what the occasion I really do hope you
give this a try very soon so head over
to food wishes comm for all the
ingredient amounts and more information
as usual and as always enjoy
